results.description:
I'll repeat the Google Wallet instructions for those unaccustomed: ***In the notes section of the payment, please leave your name and what event you are paying for! Thanks 
-Download the Google Wallet app on your phone. You'll have to have a gmail account to register your username with this service if you don't already have gmail (in that case create a gmail account first... I did the same thing awhile back just to use this service)

- Create a 4 digit PIN to sign into Google Wallet. Then you'll be on the app homepage. -The left button says 'send money'. Click it and you'll have a screen where you can input a name or email address. My email address for this is [masked] .

-Once you input my username you'll see the screen where you type in the dollar amount. Once done, click the gray 'next', then the blue 'review' button in the upper right corner. -This takes to a confirmation screen. If anything looks off just click the left button on the upper lefthand side to go back a page. Otherwise, you confirm it and click send. Done! An icon will appear in your notifications area letting you know it's sent to me.

From now on, every event will not require a payment to rsvp on this page, I will check the rsvps daily to make sure everyone followed up - any issues message me on here and we will figure it out. Please work with me and send the payment when you register for the event... after this first set up it will take ten seconds each week. If you register and don't pay within 24 hours i'll reach out to you and then have to open the spot back up.. work with me here please, that would not be fun

results.description:
Is salsa dancing and learning on your bucket list? If so, then you should come to La Fama, a Salsa dancing party that takes place every Friday in Times Square. Come out, bring your friends, and leave your worries and stress at home. With admission, you can take our complimentary FREE salsa dancing class and dance all night long to great salsa tracks played by our DJ. Here are the details:

Admission: $10. Note that this will be your only expense for the entire Friday night unless you buy a beverage. But you can also bring your own beverages if you want.

Time: The event starts at 10pm and ends at 2am or until the last dancers leave. Come at any time.

Location: Times Square 151 West 46th Street, 11th Floor, New York, NY 10036 (between 7av and 6av)

Dress code: Casual/comfortable. Bring shoes that don't slip out of your feet and do not have too much grip on the floor.

Class: The class is free with admission. It begins at 10pm and teaches you the basic steps, how to hold your partner, how to be on time with the music, and so on. You do not need to bring a dance partner since we rotate students so you get to practice with everyone else. But do bring your friends and have a blast. After the class, dance all night with all the people you met during the class. The instructor will usually be Silvio Neris unless there is an invited instructor. Here is silvio In action:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ep-cNukVLJo

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FMy3EtfWqSY

results.description:
BUY TICKETS HERE

We’re holding an indoor Glow In The Dark Party @ The Bohemian Beer Hall! Black lights will be on site, so be sure to wear things that can glow. Just an fyi, White shirts and neon shirts, will look very very cool under black lights. Bright green, orange, pink, etc. This is going to be an exciting one, so we’re definitely excited to be having this one going down.

DJ 1 (Green): Top 40 hits, Dance, Pop, etc
DJ 2 (Red): The best of 90’s, and 2K music!
DJ 3 (Blue): Hip-Hop, R&B

What the night includes:
Quiet Events Headphones
Glow in the Dark Gear
3 Live DJs battling for your attention

Special Notes:
Tickets are limited, so act fast!
This party is going on rain or shine.
Age Restriction: 21+

HOW IT WORKS

***Bring a credit or debit card for the check-in process*** When you arrive you’ll receive a pair of special wireless headphones. You can adjust the volume and choose between up to three DJs with a flip of a switch. Each headset has a color LED that shows what you are listening to, so you can dance along with those listening to the same DJ as you. It’s super social; just lower the volume or take the headphones off and talk to that girl or guy. At the end of the night, be sure to return your headphones as there will be a $100 charge to your credit or debit card if headphones don’t come back.
results.name: Glow In The Dark Madness @ Bohemian!

results.description:
We'll be heading up to Minnewaska State Park in Kerhonkson, NY to do some pre season scouting and learning what to look for. Nov 21 is opening day of rifle season but both rifle and bow hunters are welcome on this trip and Minnewaska allows bow hunting to continue through rifle season. If you are planning on hunting in Minnewaska this season will we be stopping to get permits at the park office. You will need to have already purchased your current year NYS hunting license to get a Minnewaska Permit. They need to see your back tag #. We will be able to stop at a Dick's Sporting Goods on the way to purchase hunting licenses if needed. Things we may see or discuss include- Deer behavior & why it changes
Food/water sources
Travel routes
Bedding areas
Sign - scat, scrapes, rubs
Wind and how to play it
Thermals
Patterning deer (using trail cams, etc)
Using attractants & legal concerns


This was originally mentioned to be an overnight camping trip but the campground is closed for the season and it's probably too cold anyway!

Peter and I (Eric) will both be driving and have limited group size to a max of 8. This is bow hunting season and there will be other hunters in the woods so we'd like to keep our presence to a minimum to avoid ruining the day for others. We will meet at the corner of Ashland Pl & Hanson Pl at the Williamsburg Saving Bank Tower at 5:45am.
results.how_to_find_us: Corner of Ashland Pl & Hanson Pl
results.name: Pre-Rifle Deer Season Scouting Day Trip

results.description:
Folks: I have changed the hike from the Catskills to one with similar elevation profile and *VIEWS* closer to home!

**FOR EXPERIENCED HIKERS ONLY! NOT FOR BEGINNERS! This will be an advanced hike only suitable for experienced hikers in strong physical condition!**

Fall Foliage Special. The best hike Harriman has to offer. Great views!

Distance - 23 miles

Elevation Gain - 5500'

Estimated Time - 10-12 hours 

We'll do the entire Ramapo-Dunderberg Trail from Tuxedo Park to Jones Point on 9W. Follow the red on white blazes of the R-D for its entire length. Self-reliant hikers only as there will be no sweep. You should be able to follow a map, understand possible bailouts, and must be realistic in your assessment of your own abilities. There are many trails in Harriman; they are well marked, so at all times, make sure you are on this trail .. white background, red DOT 

Gear: Harriman maps, rain gear, headlamp, lots of food and water, etc.

A car shuttle is required for this hike. 

I can pick people up at Metro-North White Plains station before 7am.

---

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below. 

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.  Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.
results.name: Ramapo-Dunderberg Traverse (23 miles) - NYC commuter friendly

Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.name: Manhattan Weekend Run

results.description:
This was accidentally deleted - Please re-RSVP if you would like to attend. 


Let's hike the perimeter of Manhattan.. a distance of
32 miles.. see the city from angles you've never seen
before. Discover neighborhoods you didn't know existed!

We will be following bike paths as much as possible, hence the zig-zagging on the east side.

The Plan:

Start at City Hall..meet just outside the 4/5/6 subway station at 8am!!.

Walk along Brooklyn Bridge to East River Dr.

Walk along East River Dr. past South Street Seaport to Battery Park.

Walk along bike path on west side of Manhattan to Gansevoort Street.

At Gansevoort Street in lower Manhattan, we will make a small detour inland to walk the High Line to W. 22nd street!!
http://www.thehighlin...

From 22nd street, get back on the bike path. Along the way we will pass Chelsea Piers, the USS Intrepid, Riverbank State Park, Fort Washington Park, the Cloisters, among other sights.

Round Spuyten Duyvil, head along W 218th street to 10th ave.

Zig-zag along the East River until we get to bike path along East River Dr. (at about 120th st)

South on East River Dr. past Carl Schurz Park down to Queensboro bridge

Head briefly west to 1st ave

South on 1st ave to 34th.

Briefly east on 34th to East River Dr.

Follow East River Dr. back to starting point!

Wear running shoes! At about 3 mph it will take us over 10 hours to do this!

Folks can go as far as they wish
results.name: *URBAN HIKING SERIES* 32 mile walk around Manhattan ** RE-POSTED**

results.description:
Join us at 8am for a run to Hoboken Pier A and back.
http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/121375029

Yes, there is a waterfront route to Hoboken. Enjoy the fun of cruising around Hoboken Pier A; around the new park and children playground at Newport where you will feel if you are at the beach. Get inspired by the man made majestic views of Manhattan!

The mapped distance is approx. 5.88 miles. You may run less or more in that time. We turn back after running 30 min to be back at 9 am. Hyatt pier is .31 miles so a double loop gets some runners 6.5 miles on this run.

9 am we run to Liberty State Park, a favorite place to run for most of us. Run on!

results.description:
When people hear about meditation, they almost always say that they have either never tried it or they were not able to do it. You may have expected that thoughts were supposed to go away, but when you closed your eyes, more thoughts than ever came up.

We invite you to come and experience how meditation can happen effortlessly with a little attention to our very own breath! The free session will include light yoga, breathing techniques and relaxing meditation and will be led by one of the volunteers of the Art of Living foundation.

Join us at Panoramic Living's Learning Landscapes Workshop. Learn Lifestyle Strategies to Live Happier, Healthier, and Longer!

Simple, yet powerful life altering practices that yield positive, sustainable results based upon scientific research of the longest living people in the world.

The workshop includes:
◾Inspiration from seven influential speakers on lifestyle transformation to help you Make Longevity Happen
◾Connection with others seeking healthier, happier lives
◾Serenity of the Planting Fields Arboretum
◾Healthy breakfast
◾Exploration post-workshop of the 400+ acres of greenhouses, rolling lawns, formal gardens & woodland paths
◾Parking

Topics and Speakers:
Connection: Boost physical and mental health plus lifespan!
Stephanie L. Brown, Ph.D
Department of Preventive Medicine SUNY at Stony Brook

Mindfulness: Reduce chronic pain, stress, and anxiety!
Barbara Edell Fisher, Ph.D.
Licensed Clinical Psychologist

Walking Wisdom: Move naturally through life!
Dr. Barry J. Fabrikant
Fabrikant Chiropractic Office

Passionate Purpose: Pump up your volume!
Linda Lombardo, CCPC
The Voice of Evolution Radio

Back to Our Roots: Eat whole foods intuitively!
Karen Sossin
Certified Nutritionist
Owner, Heart & Soul

Healthier Home: Less stuff, more freedom!
Barbara Feldman, CTRS
Owner, A Nu Start NY

Join us by registering at http://www.panoramicliving.us/news/learning-landscapes-workshop-2015/

results.description:
Weather permitting, come join us for outdoor tennis at Washington Park in Union City, which is off of the 9th Street light rail station. Bring your sweats, your racquet, plenty of water and balls and we'll see you there! As this event is not designed to match up folks, courts are assigned on first-come first-served basis. So get in early and grab a court.


Make sure you only use 3-4 of the same numbered balls. Public courts do not allow use of more than 6 balls per court.

Also please try to use the same age balls as it will help you improve your game.

You can find each other in the waiting area and/or looking on the courts. It would help if you make a mental note of the profile picture of those attending.

Although we won't enforce attendance, it would be polite to attend if you commit because others are looking to find others to hit with.

Cross your fingers that it won't rain as inclement weather cancels the event.

If you have any questions, feel free to email the organizer.

results.description:
Qi Gong is a part of traditional Chinese medicine that views and treats the body, mind and the environment as a whole. Qi Gong practices include slow body movements, meditation, and special breathing techniques. Qi Gong students can experience deep relaxation, concentration and a peaceful, clear mind. In addition, Qi Gong practices help to clear energy blockages and improve blood circulation in the body. In this class, students will learn Qi Gong exercises to increase flexibility, improve balance, reduce stress, increase concentration, and rejuvenate the mind, body, spirit and more!
No class: Nov 28, Dec 26, Jan 2.

1 game (7 v 7) : Two halves of 30 minutes each with a break in between

-Please bring a fun and chill attitude. Absolutely no rough playing, slide-tackling or berating others; You’ll be asked to leave.

-Turf, AG cleats, or sneakers - no wet ground monster spikes.

-$4.00 goes for maintaining the website, equipment, and organization.

Rules:

This is a chill game so please bring a chill attitude; no meatheads or a$$holes. Organizers have the final say (i.e. if a ball is out of bounds we call it). 
It’s a small pitch so no corners kicks; just throwins.

Directions:

How to get to Brooklyn Bridge Park PIER 2 Sports Field:

To get past the BQE, you must enter Brooklyn Bridge Park on foot either fromm the south (at Joralemon St. & Furman St.) or the north (at Old Fulton St. & Furman St.)  Pier 2 is roughly halfway between these two entrances.  We play on the artificial grass field at the far end of the pier, behind the basketball courts & roller rink.

Google these coordinates:[masked], [masked]

Brooklyn Bridge Park is accessible by several subway lines (A/C, 2/3, 4/5, F, R) and bus routes (B25, B63)

Cancellation:

We'll play rain or shine.  We'll only cancel if there are fewer than 10 people going, or if there's lightning in the area.

results.description:
Sea Stories is day focused on exploration, conservation, scuba diving, shipwrecks, nautical history and marine life. This will be a great opportunity for those who are interested in the ocean to interact. Tickets will NOT be sold at door.

Speakers to include:

Bernie Chowdhury, FN '95 and Dr. Nasreen S. Haque
"Diving for Cures: Mapping Microbial Genomics Underwater."

Mr. Chowdhury is a board-certified hyperbaric medical technologist and is the Training Director at Life Support Technologies group. He authored the book, The Last Dive, Mr. Chowdhury carried the Explorers Club Flag on two expeditions. He was named Beneath the Sea’s 2001 Diver of the Year for Education. 

Dr. Haque is the Course Director of “Evolutionary Medicine in Health and Disease” at New York Medical College. She is also the Director of the Microbial Biodiversity project, researching both marine and land-based organisms that may be useful in the development of new medications and cures for various illnesses. 

She worked at India's prestigious National Institute of Immunology where she was among the first scientists to conduct research on transgenic fish using recombinant DNA technology. 

Richie Kohler, MN ’04
“Mystery of the Last Olympian; a Decade of Exploration on Titanic's Tragic Sister, Britannic." 

Mr. Kohler led his first expedition to HMHS Britannic for the History Channel in 2006 and returned again as a member of the 2009 National Geographic film team. In the summer of 2015 Kohler returned to the HMHS Britannic leading an Explorers Club flag expedition.

His passion for maritime history led him to explore some of the most challenging shipwrecks in the world, including the identification of a WWII German U-Boat, detailed in the novel Shadow Divers. 

Mr. Kohler co-hosted the long running History Channel series, Deep Sea Detectives, and has worked on projects for Paramount Pictures, CBS, PBS, National Geographic, and the Discovery Channel. 

Anna Cummins
“More Ocean. Less Plastic.”

Ms. Cummins is a co-founder of 5 Gyres Institute, which is dedicated to understanding and communicating the issue of plastic pollution in the world's oceans. Ms. Cummins has over 10 years of experience in environmental non-profit work, education, writing, and campaign development. She has worked in marine conservation, coastal watershed management, sustainability education, and high school ecology instruction. 

Ms. Cummins received her undergraduate in History from Stanford University, and her Masters in International Environmental Policy from the Monterey Institute for International Studies. She received a fellowship from the Sustainable Communities Leadership Program, to work with Santa Cruz based non-profit Save Our Shores, coordinating bilingual outreach education and community relations.

Dr. Stephen Kajiura
“Shark Conservation - Even Predators Need a Little Help Sometimes.”

Dr Stephen Kajiura is a Professor in the Department of Biological Sciences at Florida Atlantic University. His area of expertise is the sensory biology of sharks and rays with an emphasis on the electrosensory system. He has recently applied sensory physiology to shark conservation by developing shark deterrents that repel sharks from baited hooks without affecting the catch of targeted species. 

In addition to his sensory physiology research, Dr Kajiura studies the massive seasonal aggregation of blacktip sharks in south Florida. He incorporates aerial surveys with tagging and acoustic telemetry to document the migration of these sharks along the US eastern seaboard. 

Dr Kajiura received his PhD in Zoology from the University of Hawaii, a MS in Marine Biology from the Florida Institute of Technology, and a BSc (Hons) in Marine Biology from the University of Guelph in Canada. 

Dr. Daniel Madigan
"Hot Tuna: Exploring the Connection Between the Fukushima Disaster and Pacific Bluefin Tuna."

Dr. Madigan is a researcher working on a variety of topics including large predators of the ocean sea: tunas, sharks, and marlins. 

Dr. Madigan will describe the Fukushima-derived radioactivity found in Pacific bluefin tuna caught in California as well as the ongoing discoveries of radioactivity in large Pacific predators.

He received his PhD from Stanford University in 2013, working primarily at Hopkins Marine Station in Monterey. Dr. Madigan received his BA in Biology from Dartmouth College in 2005. He spent 2 years as a National Science Foundation Fellow and is currently a Fellow at Harvard University.

results.description:
Event Description:

This will be trail maintenance hike for the beautiful but heavily used Ernest Walker Trail.  This is one of the nicest short hiking trails in New Jersey and offers breathtaking views of the Garden State, Sterling Forest, and NYC ins the distance.  This is your opportunity to give back to the hiking community while enjoying a nice day in the fresh air.

Hike Description:

From the trailhead, follow the White and Blue State Line Trail 1.25 miles to the intersection with the White Blazed Appalachian Trail.  Turn Left (south) on the AT and walk for about 1/3rd of a mile to the intersection with the Yellow Blazed Ernest Walker Trail.  Follow the Ernest Walker Trail for its entire 1.9 mile length.  Pass West and Surprise Lakes, then traverse the Bearfort Ridge Overlook with its spectacular views.  Finally, turn right back onto the White and Blue Blazed Stateline trail and walk about .75 miles to the trailhead.

Distance: ~4.1 Miles

Elevation Gain: ~1000 feet

Trailhead Parking:[masked], [masked]

Map: NYNJTC North Jersey Trails

Suggestion:

Bring work gloves and/or latex gloves. We'll be picking up garbage!

Getting There:

The Trail Head is off Lake Shore Drive across the street from a marina.  There is a yard with many boats adjacent to the parking area.  Don't park on the side with the boats. 

The Trail Head is also within walking distance of a 196/197 bus stop. The 197 Bus leaving Port Authority at 7:30 AM arrives at around 8:51 AM. The stop at the State Line is not a scheduled stop, you need to ask the driver to stop.    I'M NOT A BUS PERSON, DO YOUR OWN RESEARCH.

Apres' Hiking

After the hike we will likely go to Murhpy's in Greenwood Lake, NY or elsewhere for a quick lunch. 


    
NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back.

See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.
Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.

This is a moderately paced adventure under, over, around and through many of the amazing architectural wonders throughout Central Park. We begin our walk at the southwest tip of Central Park South and zigzag our way up the eastern half of Central Park to The Harlem Meer at 110th St. Then we circle back along the western half of the park and finish at Sheep's Meadow. Please bring water and lunch or snack for this fascinating 5-hour journey of approx. 8 miles. 

MEET: 9 AM sharp at the Atrium entrance to the Time Warner Towers Complex at 59th St. & Columbus Circle. Take the A, D or 1 train to 59th St. Rain or Shine! 

Leader: Matthew Brozyna [masked]

Contact hike leader directly if you have questions about the hike.

Free for Shorewalkers members who have paid the $20 annual membership fee, $3 for non-members. Non-members please pay the hike leader at the beginning of the hike or visit www.shorewalkers.org to join.

results.description:
We'll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery for a run on the Old Croton Aqueduct. Afterward, whoever is interested can head to the Red Barn Bakery for breakfast. This is a good run for new runners because it is out and back - no set distance to cover but you will need to wear a watch. Feel free to turnaround at any point or walk/run at your own pace. 

Details about the Saturday run

Route: We’ll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St.) in Irvington and jog VERY casually together to the Old Croton Aqueduct trail. (If you are unfamiliar with the area and would prefer to walk rather than run to the trail, click here to see the trail on a map.) From there we’ll head south toward Dobbs Ferry. There is no set distance. Everyone will walk or run at their own pace for 25 minutes, and then turn around and come back. Please wear a watch so that you know when to turn around.

Water/Bag Storage: There are very few water fountains along the route, so bring a water bottle if you need one while running. I’ll bring water and cups for after the run. There’s no bag storage, so leave belongings at home or in your car.

Location: In front of Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St, Irvington, NY 10533). Free parking is available on weekends in the MetroNorth lot next door.

</a>  <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/1452433901730637/">Join our Facebook group to post pictures or message other members.

General advice & guidelines for our regular meetup runs:

• RSVP if you are going. If your plans change, simply change your RSVP.

• There is no bag storage, so please bring only what you plan to run with.

• All regular runs are rain or shine, unless the weather is actually dangerous.

• If you arrive late, can’t find the start location, miss us for any reason, run anyway!

• If you missed RSVP deadline, and know our starting point, feel free to join us on the day – just this one time :)

Feel free to contact me either via my meetup account or at [masked] if you have any questions.

results.description:
Mileage: 4.5 - Moderate to challenging. Rugged, rocky, with some decent scrambling areas. The initial part of the trail up is steep, multiple elevation changes. A good hike for beginners who want to go to the next level.


Overview

This loop hike traverses the Bearfort Ridge, with its unusual puddingstone conglomerate rock and pitch pines growing out of bedrock, passes through a rhododendron tunnel, and comes out on the shore of Surprise Lake.

Details

Time: 5 hours


Difficulty: Moderate

Route Type: Circuit

Dogs Allowed on leash

Features:Park:

Abram Hewitt State Forest

Region: Bearfort Ridge and Wawayanda Region

Description:
For a complete hike description a route directions please visit http://www.nynjtc.org/hike/abram-s-hewitt-state-forest-0

Suggested Supplies:

Equipment: Sturdy hiking shoes. Appropriate weather gear. Water (at least 2 liters). Snacks/lunch & hiking poles (if needed). Camera. Good conversation. Positive and environmentally friendly attitude.

RISK DISCLAIMER:Please remember this is a social event and not a professionally guided hike.  By participating in this hike, you are agreeing not to hold anybody responsible for injuries or accidents, and you acknowledge hiking is a dangerous activity that could lead to injury or death. Always come prepared and equipped as if you are hiking on your own.  In the event of an emergency, your fellow hikers will do their best for you, but there is no guarantee any of the participants will have medical or rescue training.

By participating in this event you also acknowledge that you understand the level of difficulty and are physically capable, properly attired and have the necessary gear and supplies required for participation in this activity.

results.description:
A DAY WITH THE ASCENDED MASTERS

Spend a day working with the Masters to align to your own Mastery on the Earth. Join embodied channel In’Easa mabu Ishtar and receive directly from the masters El Moyra, Maitreya, Mary Magdalene, Mother Mary, Saint Germain and Lady Nada. 

During our day together these Masters will come to talk to you about why your soul is on the Earth and what it is you are here to Master and how you may do this.  Over the day you will receive processes to do, directly channeled information for yourself and wisdom that you can apply in your life.

Each Ascended Master offers to you their own Mastery - a consciousness of wisdom and enlightenment that they have mastered and anchored through their being. They are the wayshowers who come to show you the way to empower yourself and come into the Mastery of your soul on the Earth.

Mother Mary reminds you that you are a child of God and asks you to honor this in your life. She comes to call you back into the One Heart as a son and daughter of the One and reminds you that you are part of a large Family of Light. She also asks you to learn to open to receive so that you may receive the loving support and assistance that she brings to you in your times of need.

Saint Germain is the Master of the Ceremony of Life. He comes to teach you that all life is precious and each moment is a miracle that has been given to you to honor. He calls to you to choose to step from limitation in your life and to open to the greater potential that awaits you. He comes to assist you to release the control of your ego self and to learn that all that you create may be transformed through the power of light.

Lady Nada comes to assist you to resolve all that you have created that no longer serves you. As the director of the Karmic Board Lady Nada brings dispensations to you when you choose to let go of your old creations and begin to embrace what supports and nurtures you in life instead of what limits you and creates suffering. She holds the mastery of the feminine heart and comes to ask you to open to receive all that supports you and serves you to be all that you are.

El Moyra comes to talk to you about the power of your free will and to how wield it in your life to serve you. He shows you the mastery of learning to co-create with Divine Will and how this empowers you to walk in grace and wisdom on your own path - the Divine Plan for your soul. 

Mary Magdalene teaches you to open to your divine power on the Earth and embrace your true God nature. Magdalene comes to assist any soul who is ready to manifest their mission on the Earth and she brings them the strength and courage to walk this path of initiation in their lives. 

Lord Maitreya's mastery is to support humanity to open to Oneness within the greater collective and how to live on the Earth in unity without the consciousness of separation. He asks you to open your mind and your heart and to align the two together to expand and shift your consciousness to a new level. He offers you great wisdom and many keys and tools that you may apply so that you may live your spiritual self in your life every day.

TO RESERVE YOUR SEAT PLEASE CONTACT: Gale Haas:  [masked] 


COST: $125

In’Easa mabu Ishtar is an international spiritual teacher and counselor. She is an embodied Ascended Master Channel who has worked with the Masters for the past 10 years, regularly channeling high frequency wisdom teachings for groups and individuals.

Ishtar was guided and directly taught to open her pillar of light initially by Saint Germain, then Serapis Bey, Kuthumi, Mother Mary and Maitreya, Presently, she is working directly with Maitreya and Mary Magdalene to awaken the God (Christ) Consciousness on the Earth.

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Here's Our Schedule: (Times are approximate.)

10:00 - Welcome

10:15 - Show & Tell - We show things we've made since the last meeting or before and ask for help with any problems we might have encountered.

11:15-11:30 - Break for refreshments.

11:30  - Demo begins

1:00 - Meeting usually ends

$3.00 fee goes toward the cost of listing the meetings on this Meetup site.

Please bring a snack to share.

About the Demo: Please read everything.

We are making travel size tissue cases. You can use as few as two different fabrics or as many as five different fabrics. These are a really a quick project and I suggest you use whatever you already have on hand for your "SAMPLE." Tissue sizes vary by brand; you will likely have to make adjustments on your next case (at home). If we have time, we will complete 3 different cases.

Please cut and press (where appropriate) your fabrics before the meeting.

Supplies 100% cotton, straight pins, iron, ironing board, sewing machine.

Project A (use up to 5 different fabrics if you have them)

Cut 3 pieces of fabric 4" x 5 3/4" (fold 2 of these pieces in half so that you have a 2" x 5 3/4" piece) press these 2 pieces                                                                                                                                     Cut 2 pieces 4" x 4" (fold both pieces in half and press)

Project B (use 2 coordinating fabrics) Cut 1 rectangle 6" x 7 1/4"                                                                                                                            Cut 1 rectangle 6" x 8 1/4"

Project C (use 2 coordinating fabrics) One rectangle 4" x 11 1/2"                                                                                                                            One rectangle 4" x 12 1/2"

Special project for Sara (and anyone else who wants to try) - Microwave bowl holder

Supplies Fabric must be 100% COTTON with NO METALLIC THREADS

Batting - (warm and natural, wrap and zap or warm and tater [at JoAnn's] used for microwaving potatoes  Two 12" x 12" squares of fabric                                                                                                                   Two 11 1/2" x 11 1/2" squares of batting                                                                                                       Thread to match your fabric                                                                                                                          Ruler, pencil or marking pen, straight pins

Any questions on cutting, contact me prior to meeting: eoneal [masked]
results.name: Tissue Cases/Microwave Bowl Holder - Demo by Elaine

results.description:
“Shamanism goes far beyond a primarily self-centered transcendence of ordinary reality… [it’s] the helping of humankind” ~Michael Harner, The Way of the Shaman

5th Annual Shamanic Clinic, Fundraising Fair, & Celebration

NYC FREE ADMISSION! 

3 LARGE ROOMS OF!

Healing's – Readings – Lectures – Shopping 

Please bring warm socks as we need to take our shoes off in the space and want to keep your toes toasty!

At the core of its roots, shamanism, is about serving the community.  In honor of this tradition, each year the NYSC hosts its annual, “Shamanic Clinic, Fair & Celebration”.  Our largest fund-raising event, “The Clinic”, brings together a diverse team of healers and practitioners who gather in celebration to share healing, art, education, and magic.  In 2014, we offered over 20 healing modalities, including:

This Year We Offer Healings & Readings From NYSC Core Members & Guest:

Cristina Maria RojasFernandez – Energy Healing through Intuitive Touch

Christina Roman – Reiki Healing

Constantina Rhodes – Intuitive Reading

Karen Elena Rosales – Intuitive Tarot Reading

Lelia Dickerson – Tarot Reading

Guillaume Gauthereau – Reiki, Tibetan Sound Healing, Shamanic Healing

Ida Longobardi – Reiki & Infrared Light Therapy & Mayan Restoration\

Irma StarSpirit Woman – Chumpi Stone Attunement & Candle Reading

Itzhak Beery – Candle & Palm Reading

Jacques Burgering – Candle Reading

Melissa Rabe – Tui Na (Chinese Medical Massage)

Mariah Baretta – Reiki Crystal Healing

Nita Renfrew – Cherokee Bodywork & Massage

Paula Taylor – Tarot and Chakra Readings

Sage Logan – Tarot -Palmistry- African Bones -Geomancy- Ribbon Readings

Join Us For Lectures From The NY Shamanic Core-Members With New Topics Each Hour! Only $10 Per Lecture! 

11:00 am- Cristina Maria RojasFernandez- INTEGRATION: 

During & After A Profound (Spiritual) Experience. 

After undergoing a deep, transformational experience people can be left feeling unclear, fragmented verses whole, which can have lasting effects on how one fully integrates into their life.  Join us as we partner with Spirit to help us understand what makes integration so important and how to do it from a space of truth and wholeness.  Through journey work and the lens of different earth-centered traditions and the ancient medicine wheel, we will discover practices, rituals, and lessons to help us on our way.

12:00 – Irma StarSpirit Woman – “I am Crystalline Energy” 

Hands on practice working with your crystalline energy field to create abundance of the treasures of light, love, and self-healing.  Working with Crystals, sound meditations and crystal form configurations to help align our bodies and energy fields to activate and awaken enter into crystalline energy alignment.

1:00pm Jacques Burgering – The Luminous Body.

A brief lecture on the existence, workings and experiencing of the energy field around our physical bodies; and the interaction between the two.

2:00 – Spirit Guide J.D. – “Crazy New Way” 

A discussion of people, plants & power from the perspective of a Spiritual Warrior. NY Shamanic Circle’s newest core member will open up a conversation with his personal perspective on power animals, journeys, intentions, plant medicine and what it means to “Walk the Medicine Road” in the 21st century and beyond.

3:00 – Sage Logan – The FIVE Essential Energy Techniques! 

Within this talk, you will get a chance to both learn and practice, these five essential energy techniques that will allow you to restore balance in your life and connect to deep healing energies whenever you need. You will experience each method and will be able to add these skills to your own spiritual toolkit! Each of these 5 techniques has the advantage that they can be accessed in any place & at any time!

4:00 – Karen Elena Rosales – The Integration Of The Divine Feminine In Shamanism. 

One of the single most important tools in Shamanism is the drum. The sacred song of the divine mother is the heartbeat that reminds us of our soul’s mission. It imitates our heart’s rhythm and it allows us to get in touch with journeys that help us deepen our connection to the Divine Feminine.

5:00 – Itzhak Beery – Shamanism & Protection Evil Spirits Everyday.

 Each of us is surrounded by negative energies. They emanate from other people, buildings or geographical locations. You are exposed to evil eyes, bad energy, jealousy, envy, curses, invisible arrows, and more. Knowing how to protect yourself is incredibly valuable, and can help you live a healthy and happy life.

Please arrive EARLY to get a time slot for all of our healing's, readings & lectures! 

We invite you to support our mission by joining us in 2015 for another successful year! You will experience and receive powerful healing as we continue to expand and diversify our list of invited healers, teachers, and vendors.

Come for the whole day, or just stop by to say hello.Get a healing or reading session and shop for unique items at our Shamanic Fair. Invite your family and friends! 

Please email us at [masked] 

If you would like to offer Healing's & Reading sessions.

10:00am -to- 1:45pm – CLINIC / WORKSHOPS
Lunch Break in The Middle of the day
2:15pm -to- 6:00pm – CLINIC / WORKSHOPS

Please contact us for more information on this exciting opportunity!

See you on November 14th!

Shungo!
Shungo!
Shungo!

results.description:
How about an impromptu nature hike at Alley Pond Park? 


Most members are not hard core hikers so this easy/moderate hike will be to everyone's speed.

We will start with the White trail which is 0.7m long and can jump on another if we feel like after that. This park is beautiful so I hope you won't miss this.

Park Info:
Dna info's 5 best places to hike in nyc. The landscape of Queens' Alley Pond Park was formed by a glacier some 15,000 years ago — it left boulders in the green space which can still be seen today. "It's a great place to witness the remnants of long ago glacial activity as well as depressions in the earth that are now kettle ponds. The White trail roughly outlines the perimeter of the park and it is a little hilly so you get some up and down. The trail offers chances to spot hawks, as well as frogs and salamanders if you're into that sort of thang.
Numerous trails wind through native hardwood (oak-hickory) forest and kettle ponds. The north end of the park boasts splendid salt marsh views.

Meeting point: 


Parking Lot as shown on map. It is by the adventure center. Don't miss the entrance under the bridge on Winchester Blvd!

Following The Hike We'll try to grab a quick brunch nearby (More to come)

Please google transportation options.

If you're closeby and need a carpool...Make some noise in the comments!
results.name: Impromptu Nature Hike Alley Pond Park

results.description:
Bring your own ipod & earbuds. We dance walk around the park loop--everybody listens to their own music. What is dance walking? It's an improvised form of walking, with music, doing whatever movement comes naturally. It's walking and moving your arms. Or skipping, skitching, low-stepping, sideways running. It's responding to the rhythm, attitude, or story of the music you're hearing. In short, it's having a dance party in your living room, while walking through the park--hilarious and exhilarating. For inspiration, check out:

www.24hoursofhappy.com

This 1910 rowhome, located in Brooklyn's Prospect Heights neighborhood, has been completely renovated and includes a new addition and excavated cellar.  The house is fully retrofitted with the latest Passive House technologies and insulation standards.  With skylights throughout, large bay windows, and sliding glass doors, this single family home is filled natural light. Expert design and craftsmanship has brought this century old property to state-of-the-art standards while paying respect to its original character

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
